about: Ramazanoğlu Madrasa, a former school in the Old Town used until 1914, is a stunning historical site with an authentic atmosphere. Built in 1495 during the Ramazanoğulları Principality, it features rooms for state affairs and harem sections. The well-preserved stone architecture has stood for over 500 years. Visitors can enjoy a tranquil experience in the magical garden and courtyard while sipping tea or coffee.

about: Anavarza Ruins is a hidden gem that deserves more recognition. It is highly recommended to visit this historical site, especially if you have a vehicle since public transportation may not be available to the nearby village. During my visit in July 2022, I noticed that the main city gate had been recently restored and there were ongoing excavations on the main street. However, apart from these areas, the ruins are mostly covered with vegetation and used as grazing land by local shepherds.

about:
(Translated by Google) The Most Special Historical Place of GAZİANTEP
Construction of Gaziantep Castle
A Legend About:
According to the popular legend, the castle was built by a rich woman. One day, he went out on the street and came across a large crowd of people carrying a funeral. He turned to his servant next to him and asked, ""What is this?"" As for Uşak; “Sir, there will come a day when people die, they carry their dead in coffins like this, take them to the cemetery and bury them in the ground. ""In the coffin you see, there is a human corpse that was alive like us yesterday..."" he says. Thereupon, the rich woman returns with her servant and calls the masters who built the castle to her; ""Let the castle remain unfinished, I would never think of death..."" says. According to this legend, the history of Gaziantep Castle dates back to ancient times. However, there is no exact date in the legend told among these people...

GAZİANTEP'İN En Özel Tarihi Mekanı
Gaziantep Kalesinin Yapılışına
Dair Bir Efsane:
Halk arasında yaygın olarak anlatılan efsaneye göre kaleyi zengin bir kadın yaptırıyormuş. Bir gün sokağa çıkmış ve yolda kalabalık insan topluluğunun bir cenaze götürüşüne rastlamış. Gördüğünüz tabutun içinde dün bizim gibi canlı olan bir insan cesedi var……” der. Bunun üzerine zengin kadın uşağıyla beraber geri döner ve kaleyi yapan ustaları yanına çağırarak; “ bırakın kale yarım kalsın, ben ölümü hiç düşünmezdim….” der. about:
Great beach at the cost of AlacatiSam A — Google reviewIch war heute mit meiner Frau im Zio Beach Club. Die haben uns richtig abgezogen, 1500 TL eintritt, 120 TL für das Parken ( das sind ca.60€). Mir geht's nicht um das Geld, sondern das man so verarscht wird. Die Liegen verdreckt, keine Handtücher und die Lage ist nicht besonders schön. Es ist keinen Cent wert. (Translated by Google) I went to the Zio Beach Club with my wife today. They really ripped us off, 1500 TL entrance fee, 120 TL for parking (that's about €60). It's not about the money, it's about being ripped off like that. The loungers were dirty, no towels and the location wasn't particularly nice. It's not worth a cent.
See more
B D — Google review
Rise & Shine Beach Club I could write poetry about how I hate places that are beautifully designed but employ people that make you feel like they are doing you a favor by letting you in or make you work for it even though you are paying 100 Lira. adress: Alaçatı, 35930 Çeşme/İzmir, Türkiye•http://spiaggiagrande.com/•+90 530 088 41 11•Tips and more reviews for Spiaggia Grande Beach
about:
We decided to ignore the most recent mild/negative reviews and were pleasantly surprised at how great this place was. I would say it’s a ‘Western’-standard beach club (No offence meant - I am Turkish!) with attentive staff, great facilities, really nice private strip of beach, really good food (better than usual beach club grub - the burrata salad and tenderloin penne were superb) and overall we had a super experience and felt like we were on a proper holiday. Other people visiting seemed nice too which can make a difference (i.e. there were no annoying / loud groups or anything). I get the comments about the price - it is a bit pricey for Turkey but what you get is better as well. It’s overall just a very pleasant experience and if you don’t want to faff with stuff and want a nice beach club this place is great. It is actually not even that expensive to be honest - 90 TL entrance which includes a beer; 40 TL for valet; and we spent 420 TL on a full lunch for two, couple of cocktails, almost non stop soft drinks coming and a complementary fruit platter. 650 TL which is about £85 for a full day for two; very cheap by European standards (you would pay about €200-250 for the same in Mykonos and it would only be slightly better) but a little more than the standard Turkish place. I guess you pay a bit more for access to the front beds or the better lounge areas but to be honest so what, the sun beds in the middle are just as nice! One tip for the venue would be to up the music volume a bit - playlist was actually quite good but volume just a bit too soft.

Pigeon Valley and Ilhara Valley are also worth visiting in the area.

The area is rich in history, with many of these unique structures being used as homes dating back to the 3rd century. Visitors can enjoy a leisurely walk amidst the stunning natural scenery and explore the cave churches that are scattered along the trail.

about: Hot Air Balloon Göreme offers a magical experience of watching hundreds of hot air balloons fill the sky at sunrise, creating a fairytale-like scene. The lunar-like landscapes, shaped by natural erosion over millions of years, are rich in history and offer a mesmerizing backdrop for activities like trekking, bike-riding, and horse-riding. The Cappadocia Hotel provides cave-engraved rooms with unique designs and terraces overlooking the spectacular fairy chimney landscape.

about: Nestled within the Goreme Open Air Museum, Çarıklı Kilise (the Church with Sandals) is a 13th-century rock-cut marvel adorned with captivating frescoes. The church features depictions of the four gospel writers and the Betrayal of Judas under its central dome. Accessible via an iron staircase behind St. Catherine chapel, this hidden gem boasts a dining hall with a long, narrow table carved into the rock and seating around it.

about: The Chapel of Saint Barbara is a place of worship dedicated to a devout woman who faced persecution from her father during the early days of Christianity. Despite enduring unimaginable suffering, she remained faithful to her Christian beliefs and ultimately became one of the first Christian martyrs. The church itself is located behind the rock where Elmali Church is situated. It has a unique cruciform design with two columns, domed corners, and an impressive fresco depicting Christ Pantocrator that catches the eye.

name: Azize Barbara Şapeli

tag3: Zelve Open Air Museum is a significant cave village that was home to both Christians and Muslims until 1924. It boasts religious paintings and intricately carved buildings, offering visitors an incredible experience. The entrance fee is around 25 liras per person, and a taxi from the village may cost between 40-50 liras. You can also arrange with your driver to wait for you while you explore for approximately 120 liras.

tag3: The Haji Bektash Veli Complex is a cultural center and pilgrimage site for Alevi Muslims. It houses the tomb of Pir Sultan Haci Bektas Veli, a medieval saint, and features cultural exhibits and gardens. The museum structure in the courtyard is noteworthy, with an interesting dome-topped tomb. Visitors can drink holy water from the Lions fountain at the entrance.

tag3: The Nevsehir Museum, established in 1987, showcases cultural and archaeological artifacts from the Cappadocian region spanning three thousand years. Despite limited written explanations, the museum's exhibits on ethnography and ancient history are interesting. Although it is smaller than other museums in the region, entrance to this free museum creates a peaceful atmosphere for visitors. However, some may find that its collection of items is comparatively weaker due to neglect by its caretakers.

Visitors should note that sun protection like umbrellas are not provided here so you need to come prepared with your own.

Visitors can indulge in various activities such as exploring different parts of the hill or taking souvenir photos at reasonable prices. However, visitors with mobility issues may struggle with steep staircases leading to some parts of the park.

Although not heavily touristic due to its remote location and steep ascent, the preserved ruins are well worth a visit.

adress: Haşimişcan, Fevzi Çakmak Cd. No:11, 07100 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye•https://muze.gov.tr/muze-detay?SectionId=AAE01&DistId=MRK•+90 242 241 15 27•Tips and more reviews for Ataturk House & Museum
about: The Ataturk House Museum is a replica of the mansion where Mustafa Kemal Atatürk (1881-1938) had his home and office during his presidency from 1923 to 1938. The museum has period furnishings, photos and personal effects on display, as well as English translations of all displays. It is a wonderful place to have historical experience, and there is no charge for entry.
formatted_address: Bey Ali Özalgan Sokak No:4, 27010 Şahinbey/Gaziantep, Türkiye
name: Atatürk Müzesi

adress: Selçuk Mah Yat Limanı Sok. No:112, 07000 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye•http://oyuncakmuzesi.antalya.bel.tr/•+90 242 248 49 33•Tips and more reviews for Antalya Toy Museum
about: The Antalya Toy Museum is a small museum in Antalya, Turkey that exhibits a range of whimsical toys dating from the 1860s to the 1990s. The museum is located in two buildings and has several rooms that are dark when you enter but can be lit with motion-controlled lights. The museum is free to visit, and contains a nice collection of old toys.
formatted_address: Selçuk Mah Yat Limanı Sok. No:112, 07000 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye
name: Antalya Oyuncak Müzesi

adress: Barbaros Mah. Kocatepe Sok, Kaleiçi No: 25, 07100 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye•http://akmed.ku.edu.tr/•+90 242 243 42 74•Tips and more reviews for Suna & İnan Kıraç Kaleiçi Museum
about: The Almed Suna-Inan Kirac Museum is a small but interesting museum with plenty of valuable exhibits on the history of Çanakkale. There are also dioramas depicting 19th century life in Turkey, and a former church exhibiting Çanakkale ceramics. The museum is well worth a visit, especially if you're interested in Turkish history.
formatted_address: Barbaros Mah. Kocatepe Sok, Kaleiçi No: 25, 07100 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye
name: Suna & İnan Kıraç Kaleiçi Müzesi / Kaleici Museum

adress: Tuzcular, Uzun Çarşı Sk. No:3, 07100 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye•Tips and more reviews for Tekeli Mehmet Pasa Mosque
about: The Tekeli Mehmet Pasha Mosque is a 17th-century Ottoman structure located near the entrance of Antalya Castle. It is named after a powerful 16th-century grand vizier of the Ottoman Empire. The mosque features a domed roof supported by half-domes from the east-west and south directions, with three additional domes on its northern facade. Tile panels in talik adorn the pointed arch-shaped pediments of windows inside the building.
formatted_address: Tuzcular, Uzun Çarşı Sk. No:3, 07100 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye
name: Tekeli Mehmet Paşa Cami

adress: Kızılsaray, Milli Egemenlik Cd., 07040 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye•Tips and more reviews for Murat Pasha Mosque
about: The Murat Pasha Mosque was constructed during the Ottoman Empire in 1570 and features three domes and renowned calligraphy. The mosque boasts excellent tile work on its ceiling and a lovely orange tree in its grounds. While it is small, built in 1558, the mosque remains a place for performing prayers such as zuhur and jenazah. Visitors can experience a serene ambiance when walking around the garden or listening to birds singing early morning.
formatted_address: Kızılsaray, Milli Egemenlik Cd., 07040 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye
name: Murat Paşa Camii

about: The Deepo Outlet Center is a discount outlet mall in Antalya, Turkey that is popular with locals because it is much cheaper than other shopping centers. The outlets at the mall are constantly on sale, making it an ideal place to shop for fashion and household items. In addition to domestic shoppers, the mall attracts tourists who come to Antalya to visit.
formatted_address: Altınova Sinan, Serik Cd. No:309, 07170 Kepez/Antalya, Türkiye
name: Deepo Outlet Center

adress: Kılınçarslan, Hesapçı Sk. No:45, 07100 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye•Tips and more reviews for Sultan Alaaddin Camii
about: The Sultan Alaaddin Mosque is a small, hidden mosque that was originally an Greek Orthodox church. It was converted to a mosque in 1958, and the original painted ceiling with its intricate star motifs has been preserved. The mosque is one of the best galleries in Antalya and is highly recommended for tourists.
formatted_address: Kale, Alitaş Sk., 06250 Altındağ/Ankara, Türkiye
name: Sultan Alaaddin Camii

adress: Kalkan, 07580 Kemer/Kaş/Antalya, Türkiye•Tips and more reviews for Kaputaş Beach
about: Kaputaş Beach is a stunning shoreline cradled between two massive rock formations. To avoid the crowds, it's best to arrive early and depart early since it can become very crowded with both locals and tourists. Bring cash for rental of chairs and umbrellas, although the food leaves much to be desired, but there are decent bathroom facilities available on-site. Visitors should note that sun protection like umbrellas are not provided here so you need to come prepared with your own.
formatted_address: Kaputaş Plajı, Kalkan, 07580 Kemer/Kaş/Antalya, Türkiye
name: Kaputaş Plajı

adress: Kursunlu Şelalesi, 07119 Aksu/Antalya, Türkiye•https://kursunluwaterfall.com/•+90 242 433 22 18•Tips and more reviews for Kurşunlu Waterfall
about: Kurşunlu Waterfall is a vast natural park spanning 587 hectares and is situated along one of the tributaries of Aksu River. The park features several picturesque picnic areas, a waterfall, and a range of nature trails through the mountains. Visitors can indulge in various activities such as exploring different parts of the hill or taking souvenir photos at reasonable prices. However, visitors with mobility issues may struggle with steep staircases leading to some parts of the park.
formatted_address: Kursunlu Şelalesi, 07119 Aksu/Antalya, Türkiye
name: Kurşunlu Şelalesi Tabiat Parkı

adress: Söğütcük, 07800 Döşemealtı/Antalya, Türkiye•https://muze.gov.tr/muze-detay?sectionId=TRM01&distId=TRM•Tips and more reviews for Termessos Ruins
about: Termessos Ruins is an ancient Pisidian city situated on Güllük Mountain, accessible through hiking trails. Nestled within Mount Gulluk-Termessos National Park, this historical landmark stands over 1,000 feet above sea level and offers breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape. Although not heavily touristic due to its remote location and steep ascent, the preserved ruins are well worth a visit.
formatted_address: Söğütcük, 07800 Döşemealtı/Antalya, Türkiye
name: Termessos Antik Kenti

name: Sapadere

adress: Selçuk, 07100 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye•Tips and more reviews for Kaleici Panoramic Elevator
about: The Kaleici Panoramic Elevator in Antalya Bay is a popular tourist attraction that provides views of the city and the surrounding area. The glass elevator runs between ground level and the old harbor, making it a convenient way to reach the site without having to climb steep hills or navigate around tight corners. In February, there was no queue, but during peak season the lift can get very crowded.
formatted_address: Selçuk, 07100 Muratpaşa/Antalya, Türkiye
name: Kaleici Panoramic Elevator

about: Aktur Park is an amusement park in Antalya that offers pay-per-attraction roller coasters, kids' rides, and carnival games. It's a great place to spend a day with activities suitable for all ages. The entrance is easy with clear ticket options and reasonable prices for the rides. There are various attractions like the heart of Antalya and Go kart with minimal queues. However, food, drinks, and toilets need to be paid separately which can be a bit inconvenient.
formatted_address: Pınarbaşı, Atatürk Blv. No:4, 07070 Konyaaltı/Antalya, Türkiye

Julieth T — Google review
(Translated by Google) Kaş is a magnificent holiday resort located on the southern coast of Turkey. This charming town in Antalya province fascinates its visitors with its historical and natural beauties. Kaş is an indispensable destination for holidaymakers with its ancient ruins, turquoise sea and unique beaches. The biggest attraction of Kaş is that it is located at the intersection of the Aegean and the Mediterranean. Therefore, it is home to a rich marine life and amazing diving spots. For diving lovers, Kaş is considered one of the best diving sites in the world. Underwater, you can encounter colorful coral reefs, shipwrecks and various sea creatures. However, Kaş is not limited to diving only. Historical ruins include the ancient theatre, Lycian rock tombs and the ancient harbour. These ruins offer visitors the opportunity to explore the history of the area. At the same time, it offers a historical atmosphere with its narrow streets and traditional houses in the city center. The natural beauties of Kaş are also astonishing. The small beaches on the coast are like paradise with their crystal clear waters. Places such as Kalkan, Kaputaş and Patara beaches are excellent options for those who want to sunbathe and enjoy the sea. Additionally, Kaş's impressive mountain view and natural parks attract the attention of nature lovers. Kaş also has an impressive nightlife. Restaurants, cafes and bars offer visitors delicious food and a fun atmosphere. The port area comes alive especially in the evenings and is famous for its restaurants serving local and international cuisine. As a result, Kaş is one of the most popular holiday destinations in Turkey with its natural and historical beauties. It attracts the attention of all kinds of holidaymakers with its ancient ruins, clear sea, beautiful beaches and lively nightlife. If you are looking for an unforgettable holiday experience, Kaş should definitely be on your list. I hope this article has provided you with enough information about Kaş Antalya. If you have any other questions or requests, I'm happy to help. (Original) Kaş, Türkiye'nin güney sahilinde bulunan muhteşem bir tatil beldesidir. Antalya iline bağlı olan bu şirin kasaba, tarihi ve doğal güzellikleriyle ziyaretçilerini büyülemektedir. Antik dönemden kalma kalıntılar, turkuaz renkteki denizi ve benzersiz plajlarıyla Kaş, tatilciler için vazgeçilmez bir destinasyondur. Kaş'ın en büyük çekiciliği, Ege ve Akdeniz'in kesiştiği noktada yer almasıdır. Bu nedenle, zengin bir deniz yaşamına ve muhteşem dalış noktalarına ev sahipliği yapmaktadır. Dalış severler için Kaş, dünyanın en iyi dalış bölgelerinden biri olarak kabul edilmektedir. Suyun altında, renkli mercan resifleri, batıklar ve çeşitli deniz canlılarıyla karşılaşabilirsiniz. Ancak Kaş sadece dalışla sınırlı değildir. Tarihi kalıntılar arasında antik tiyatro, Likya kaya mezarları ve antik liman yer almaktadır. Bu kalıntılar, ziyaretçilere bölgenin tarihini keşfetme fırsatı sunar. Aynı zamanda, şehir merkezindeki dar sokakları ve geleneksel evleriyle tarihi bir atmosfer sunar. Kaş'ın doğal güzellikleri de hayranlık uyandırıcıdır. Sahildeki küçük plajlar, kristal berraklığındaki sularıyla adeta birer cennettir. Kalkan, Kaputaş ve Patara plajları gibi yerler, güneşlenmek ve denizin keyfini çıkarmak isteyenler için mükemmel seçeneklerdir. Ayrıca, Kaş'ın etkileyici dağ manzarası ve doğal parkları da doğa severlerin ilgisini çekmektedir. Kaş ayrıca etkileyici bir gece hayatına sahiptir. Restoranlar, kafeler ve barlar, ziyaretçilere lezzetli yemekler ve eğlenceli bir atmosfer sunar. Özellikle akşamları liman bölgesi canlanır ve yerel ve uluslararası mutfaklardan lezzetler sunan restoranlarıyla ünlüdür. Sonuç olarak, Kaş, doğal ve tarihi güzellikleriyle Türkiye'nin en gözde tatil beldelerinden biridir. Antik kalıntılar, berrak denizi, güzel plajları ve canlı gece hayatıyla her türlü tatilcinin ilgisini çekmektedir. Eğer unutulmaz bir tatil deneyimi arıyorsanız, Kaş mutlaka listenizde yer almalıdır. Umarım bu makale, Kaş Antalya hakkında size yeterli bilgi sağlamıştır. Eğer başka bir sorunuz veya isteğiniz varsa, yardımcı olmaktan mutluluk duyarım.

about: Xanthos Travel offers a glimpse into the rich history of Kalkan, formerly known as Kalamaki, where Greek and Turkish influences blend. The area served as a vital trade hub during the Ottoman Empire, with camels transporting goods from Xanthos valley and beyond. Visitors can explore this heritage on the Kekova-Sunken City Boat Trip, guided by knowledgeable experts like Baran Turemis.

about: Scuba diving in Kaş offers an unforgettable experience for diving enthusiasts. The crystal-clear waters of the Mediterranean provide excellent visibility and a diverse marine life to explore. With several dive sites suitable for all levels, including underwater caves and ancient shipwrecks, Kaş is a paradise for adventure seekers. Experienced instructors and well-equipped dive centers ensure a safe and enjoyable diving experience. Whether you're a beginner or an experienced diver, Kaş has something incredible to offer beneath the waves.

adress: Andifli, 07580 Kaş/Antalya, Türkiye•Tips and more reviews for Hellenistic theatre
about: The Hellenistic Theatre in Kas is a well-preserved horseshoe-shaped amphitheatre with typical ancient Greek features. Dating back to the 1st century BC and later restored, it boasts a round orchestra that once accommodated choirs and around 4,000 spectators. The top tier offers breathtaking views, making it a popular spot for locals to quietly watch the sunset or sunrise. Adjacent to quality restaurants, including a vegan option, visitors can enjoy the stunning scenery before dining out.

I think I saw some change rooms at the top of the steps that lead down.

about: Lycia Rock Tombs are a hidden gem nestled between apartment blocks, marked by a yellow sign. Following the white electricity cables leads to more tombs, but be prepared for some rock scrambling and wear appropriate attire due to prickly bushes. The tombs are built directly into the rock face and offer a glimpse into Lycian cultures. Climbing is necessary to access some tombs, so caution is advised, especially at night.

adress: Andifli, Süleyman Sandıkçı Sk., 07580 Kaş/Antalya, Türkiye•http://www.batinboat.com/•+90 532 540 91 84•Tips and more reviews for Batın Boat Tours
about: Batın Boat Tours offers an exceptional day trip experience, taking visitors to explore small islands and secluded bays with clear waters. The boat is well-maintained and Captain Ali ensures a friendly and fun atmosphere for all guests. adress: Andifli, Atatürk Blv., 07580 Kaş/Antalya, Türkiye•Tips and more reviews for Lion Tomb
about:
(Translated by Google) The tombs and sarcophagi of the Lycians, who believe in the immortality of the soul and are not afraid of death, are found all over the geography. The lion sarcophagus, which should be seen at the end of Uzunçarşı street, is one of them. Dating to the 4th century BC, the symbol of Kas, the Lion Tomb lies in the shadow of a plane tree. Lycian sarcophagi look like miniature houses with their roof-to-door lids and small window holes on them. On the public side, this sarcophagus is called ""blind"". There are cute streets that extend from Kaş Square to the left and right. Kaş Uzunçarşı, the most beautiful of these, is beautiful enough to make people fall in love with its old houses and cats, which are embroidered with bougainvillea, which are processed as shops today. Old houses, restaurants with gardens, boutique hotels with few rooms are lined up on the streets that are connected to Uzun Çarşı, left and right. The second burial chamber in the monumental Aslanite Sarcophagus, located on Uzunçarşı Avenue in Kaş, was built from a single block. The sarcophagus, probably thought to belong to a king or commander, has a magnificent appearance made by placing two sarcophagus boats in a row. In this respect, it also has a monumental atmosphere. There is an 8-line Lycian inscription on the pedestal of the sarcophagus. Because the monument to instill fear on both sides of the cover gaping four lion's head located was called the Lion sarcophagus sarcophagus. The lion heads, which serve as watchmen, act as handles on the cover. There are two figures facing the sarcophagus. On the left is a thoughtful old figure, half-dressed, leaning against his bat and crossing his legs. On the right side on a chair, there is a female figure sitting on the lap of his hands. On the upper side, two figures from the front are shown standing. Of these, a half-dressed man has a cape hanging from his left shoulder. When you turn right after the sarcophagus, you can go to the small streets where the most decent restaurants of Kaş are lined up. (Original) Ruhun ölümsüzlüğüne inanan ve bu yüzden ölümden korkmayan Likyalıların mezar ve lahitlerine coğrafyanın her yerinde rastlanıyor. Uzunçarşı sokağının bitiminde görülmesi gereken Aslanlı Lahit de bunlardan biri. Kaş’ın simgesi olan MÖ 4. yüzyıla tarihlenen Aslanlı Lahit, bir çınar ağacının gölgesinde yatıyor. Likya lahitleri çatı görevindeki kapağı ve üstündeki küçük pencere delikleriyle minyatür evlere benziyor. Halk tarafında bu lahde ‘körüstan’ adı verilmiş. Kaş Meydan’dan sağa sola uzayan şirin sokaklar var. Bunlardan en güzeli olan Kaş Uzunçarşı, bugün dükkan olarak işetilen, begonvillerle sarmalanmış cumbalı eski evleri ve kedileriyle insanı kendisine aşık ettirecek kadar güzel. Uzunçarşıya sağlı sollu bağlanan sokaklarda eski evler, bahçeli restoranlar, az odalı butik oteller sıralanıyor. Kaş’ta Uzunçarşı caddesi üzerinde yer alan anıtsal Aslanlı Lahit’te ikinci mezar odası tek bir bloktan yapılmış. Muhtemelen bir kral veya komutana ait olduğu düşünülen lahit, üst üste iki lahit teknesi konularak yapılmış muhteşem bir görünüme sahip. Bu yönüyle anıtsal bir havası da var. Lahdin kaidesinde 8 satırlık Likya dilinde bir kitabesi bulunuyor. Anıtın kapağının iki yanında korku salacak şekilde ağzı açık dört aslan kafası yer aldığından bu lahit Aslanlı Lahit olarak adlandırılmış. Bekçilik görevini üslenen aslan başları kapağa tutamak görevi yapıyor. Lahit üzerinde karşı karşıya iki figür var. Solda yarı giyimli, sopasına dayanmış ve bacak bacak üstüne atmış düşünceli bir yaşlı figür yer alıyor. Sağ tarafta ise bir sandalye üzerinde, ellerini kucağında oturan bir kadın figürü var. Üst tarafta da cepheden iki figür ayakta gösterilmiş. Bunlardan yarı giyimli erkeğin sol omuzundan sarkan pelerin bulunuyor. Lahdin ardından hemen sağa dönünce Kaş’ın en nezih restoranlarının sıralandığı küçük sokaklara çıkılıyor

""Kaş: Unveiling the Splendor of Nature and the Mesmerizing Hues of the Aegean at Kaş Municipality Public Beach"" In the enchanting Turkish town of Kaş, a trove of natural splendor awaits, where azure skies meet the shimmering Aegean Sea, creating a panorama that leaves every visitor spellbound. Nestled on the peninsula side, the Kaş Municipality Public Beach is one such gem that embodies the region's sublime beauty. Bathing in the warm Turkish sun, this beach captivates with its distinct charm. The sea here is a painting brought to life - a stunning blend of varying shades of blue that ripple out into the horizon. From the clearest turquoise close to the shore to deeper hues further out, the sea around Kaş is a spectacle that truly evokes the majesty of the Aegean. Adding to this picturesque scene is the pebbly shoreline, a layer of small stones that gently massages your feet as you walk along the water's edge. The calming sound of these pebbles shifting under the gentle sway of the sea sets the rhythm for a serene and tranquil day at the beach. While this heavenly retreat allows you to bask in nature's grandeur, it also caters to your gastronomic needs. The on-site facility serves a range of delights, including juicy hamburgers, crispy french fries, and an assortment of cold and hot beverages. To top it off, the prices are fairly moderate, ensuring that your beach day is not only enjoyable but also light on the pocket. In essence, the Kaş Municipality Public Beach is an oasis that provides a perfect amalgamation of spectacular natural beauty and comfort. It's a destination that lets you lose yourself in the stunning vistas of the Aegean while ensuring you have all you need for a delightful beach day. So when in Kaş, make sure this beach is on your must-visit list. The exceptional beauty of this spot is indeed an experience you won't want to miss.

about:
Located on the Lycian train, this wonderful is a must see. You will walk through Lycian ruins, including numerous tombs. There is a camp site and a cafe/ restaurant/ pensiyon closehe site, adjacent to the sea. Great spot to go for a swim and spend the night!

Mahgul J — Google review
Aperlai is a ancient city on the edge of the Mediterranean see. The city is accessed by boat with daily boat trips heading out from the nearby city of Kas. The ancient city extends down into the sea with re remains of houses and lighthouse. Where else in the world can you jump off your boat and swim among the ancient ruins! You can also venture onto the land and explore the houses factories and tombs. Because of its location the area is totally unspoilt with limited numbers of visitors. The water is clear and warm with shelter provided by the headland. Yet again Turkey demonstrates it’s rich history and extensive archaeological treasures.

Nice little beach on the D400, right at a sharp bend in the road. Chairs/ umbrella 60TL each. Chairs have cushions (if you get there early enough). Beach is all pebbles and stone, small. But it's not crowded, being a bit out of the way. Parking is good, both sides of the road. The cafe and WC are across the very busy road. WC is pretty good. Showers are there. The cafe seems not very good, most folks orderfries. Water is clean and clear, a bit wavy, a bit cold (June). Maybe 5m to deep so perfect for the kids. Go there for a quiet beach experience and bring your own food and drink. Be careful on that road. Heavy trucks go whizzing around the corner.
